Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54002-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance Facility (F-TRTA) 
April 2020 
 
 
 
Southeast Asia Agriculture, Natural Resources and 
Rural Development Facility – Phase II 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ANR  –  agriculture, natural resources and rural development 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Division (SEER), SERD

territory or area.

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
A.  Justification 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will provide project preparation and 
implementation support, capacity building and policy advice to a series of ensuing and ongoing 
projects in the agriculture, natural resources and rural development (ANR) sector in developing 
member countries (DMCs) in Southeast Asia in line with the Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s 
Strategy 2030 during 2020–2025. The ANR sector plays a key role in ensuring inclusive economic 
growth in the region and has high priority in the respective national development strategies. The 
TA facility will enhance efficiency in project preparation by (i) reducing TA processing time; and 
(ii) streamlining consultant recruitment by engaging prequalified consultants. This TA facility is 
listed in the respective DMC country operations business plan.1 
 
1.  Background 
2.  Remarkable economic growth and poverty reduction. The Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) region, comprising 10 Southeast Asian countries, is home to over 622 
million people. It has the third largest labor force in the world, behind only the People’s Republic 
of China and India. With an average annual economic growth of 5.3% during 2007–2018, ASEAN 
has consistently outperformed global economic growth. ASEAN’s combined gross domestic 
products in 2017 stood at $2.8 trillion (sixth largest economy in the world).2 The robust economic 
performance enabled the region to reduce the proportion of populations below the respective 
national poverty lines from 31% in 1990 to 14% in 2015 (footnote 2). The economic growth and 
poverty reduction achievements, however, are at risk due to the spread of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic. Any health or climate induced shocks negatively impact the entire food 
supply chain, from production all the way to consumers. Mitigating these shocks and building a 
diverse, competitive, safe and sustainable agricultural sector will be a major objective for DMCs. 
 
3.  Increasing rural-urban income disparity. Despite the remarkable poverty reduction, 
there are still 36 million people in the region living below the international poverty line.3 The 
economic growth driven by industrial and service sectors centered in urban areas has left the 
large population in rural areas outside the stream of viable economic opportunities. The widening 
rural-urban income disparity within countries has been recognized as a common symptom.4 
Investing in urban development is not sufficient to make economic growth equitable, inclusive and 
sustainable. Vitalizing rural economies is imperative as the region is endowed with rich agricultural 
and natural resources, and with large populations engaged in agriculture. 
 
2.  Sector Challenges 
4.  Low rural labor productivity. The increasing rural-urban income disparity is largely 
attributable to low rural labor productivity. The DMCs have substantial rural populations, whose 
shares in total populations vary from the lowest in Indonesia (46.3%) to the highest in Cambodia 
(79.3%). Rural labor opportunities in the region are largely in rice-dominant, small-scale, and low 
 
1  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Cambodia, 2020–2022. Manila; ADB. 2019. Country Operations 
Business Plan: Lao People's Democratic Republic, 2020–2022. Manila; ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business 
Plan: Myanmar, 2020–2022. Manila; and ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Philippines, 2020–2022. 
Manila.  
2  Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). 2019. ASEAN Key Figures 2019. Jakarta. 
3  ASEAN Secretariat News. 2017. Launched: Publication on financing the Sustainable Development Goals in ASEAN. 
News release.  
4  Not a single ASEAN nation could be considered one of the more equitable economies globally. A. Mordecai. 2017. 
What is the Future of Integration and Inequality in ASEAN? The Diplomat. 15 September.

2 
mechanized farming.5 A large portion of the rural workforce is engaged in subsistent agriculture 
and underemployed. It is crucial for the DMCs to generate productive economic opportunities for 
rural populations by diversifying the sector and building backward and forward linkages within the 
sector. Building a skilled domestic labor force also reduces the dependency on outside labor 
migration and strengthens the country to labor supply shocks. At the same time, current gender 
imbalances must be addressed. In most Southeast Asian countries, agriculture still accounts for 
over half of all women’s employment. However, women or female headed households are 
estimated to receive less agriculture extension services than their male counterparts, have less 
land and limited access to farm equipment, tools, and communications services. 
 
5.  Increasing demand for a wide variety of safe food. Due to increased income and 
awareness for a safe and balanced diet, the people in the region demand a variety of high quality 
and more nutritious food products. Overall, incidence of malnutrition remains relatively high, 
disproportionately affecting women and children. Because food products are produced and 
transported by multiple players in the food value chains, it is more difficult to trace causes of food 
adulteration and contamination. Furthermore, there needs to be an effort to improve health, safety, 
and trade in livestock and livestock products by establishing transboundary animal disease control 
zones and strengthening livestock value chains. While food safety laws have become more 
stringent in the DMCs, their capacity to enforce food safety laws is still limited. The extended food 
value chains and wide variety of food products have made law enforcement on food safety control 
a challenge.  
 
6.  Underdeveloped agro-based value chains. To achieve inclusive growth in the region, 
the ANR sector needs to become more competitive and generate productive off- and non-farm 
jobs. Agro-based value chain development is the key to realize this. However, value chains of 
most agriculture products in the DMCs are underdeveloped because of insufficient private sector 
investment caused by various constraints: (i) underdeveloped infrastructure; (ii) limited access to 
long-term affordable finance for a great majority of business entities in the sector (i.e., micro-, 
small- and medium-sized enterprises and cooperatives); and (iii) sourcing raw materials from 
many scattered small farmers. 
 
7.  Low irrigation efficiency. Low productivity and yield are also often affected by low 
irrigation coverage and efficiency. Frequently, areas do not receive sufficient irrigation water due 
to dysfunctional and aging infrastructure, resulting in considerable loss of opportunities for 
increased productivity. Many canal networks and structures have high water losses and poor 
operational  efficiency  due  to  inappropriate  designs,  improper  planning,  non-adoption  of 
appropriate technologies, inadequate operation and maintenance, and aging. 
 
8.  Natural resources degradation and environmental pollution. The region is endowed 
with rich natural resources, which are pivotal in sustaining a wide range of economic activities 
and livelihoods. However, intensive agricultural growth has caused immense natural resources 
degradation  and  environmental  pollution.  Environmentally  unsustainable  farming  practices, 
resource-intensive industrial agricultural production, poor management of commercial plantations, 
and an increasing volume of agricultural products that require transport have all contributed to the 
degradation of natural resources and environmental pollution. It is important to take a holistic 
approach to make the performance of agro-based value chains resource-efficient and green. 
 
9.  Climate change impacts. The region is highly vulnerable to climate change as a large 
proportion of population and economic activity is concentrated along coastlines and water bodies. 
 
5  Average agricultural land per capita ranges from 0.36 hectare in Cambodia as the largest and 0.12 hectare in 
Viet Nam as the smallest.

3 
The region relies heavily on agriculture, the most climate vulnerable sector, for livelihood. 
Although the region’s contribution to global greenhouse emissions is relatively low, the Intended 
Nationally Determined Contributions under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change identifies the 
region’s  increasing  energy  use  in  agriculture,  industry,  and  transportation,  together  with 
deforestation and land-use change as the main factors for the rise in greenhouse gas emissions.6 
An ADB study projected that the region may lose up to 11% of gross domestic product by 2100 if 
no action is taken to address climate change.7 
 
3.  Opportunities 
10.  Promotion of advanced technologies. The TA facility will help prepare and implement 
investment  projects  and  programs  that  will  address  the  above-mentioned  challenges  and 
capitalize on the opportunities. These projects and programs will continue to (i) promote the use 
of  climate-smart  agricultural  practices;  (ii)  promote  the  adoption  of  advanced  technologies 
(iii) ensure the sustainable use of land and water resources;  (iv) enhance disaster preparedness 
and climate resilience (including early warning systems); and (v) promote inter-governmental 
coordination. The projects will strengthen public infrastructure and services (e.g., irrigation, rural 
roads, public markets, and food safety-related facilities and services) to create enabling ANR 
sector development and business environments for agro-based value chain stakeholders. In 
particular,  investing  in  infrastructure,  capacity  building,  and  policies  for  livestock  disease 
monitoring, preparedness and control can increase productivity, inclusiveness, sustainability, and 
resilience of GMS livestock value chains, and contribute to the global COVID-19 responses and 
reduce the risk of future emerging infectious diseases with pandemic potential. The projects will 
also promote private sector investment to accelerate growth by increasing productivity and value 
addition and ensure the quality of growth by improving food safety and environmental controls. 
They will incorporate gender designs and targets to improve and support women’s participation 
in and benefiting from these operations.  
 
11.  The  TA  facility  will  support  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  and  its  operational  priorities  by 
(i) promoting rural development and food security; (ii) addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental sustainability; (iv) fostering regional cooperation and integration; (v) strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity; and (vi) accelerating progress in gender equality.8  
 
12.  Lessons  learned  from  previous  TA  facility.  The  TA  facility  for  Southeast  Asia 
Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development Facility approved in December 2018, is 
the first TA facility to provide project preparation and implementation support for the ANR sector 
in the Southeast Asia region.9 Preliminary results show time savings in (i) securing one-time 
government no-objection letters to support preparation of several ensuing projects; and (ii) the 
consultant recruitment by doing one-time advertisement and prequalifying eight consulting firms 
to prepare five ensuing projects. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
13.  Output 1: ANR sector projects prepared. The TA facility will assist the DMCs in 
 
6  Synthesis of intended nationally determined contributions as communicated by Parties. United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change. Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (accessed 12 November 2019). 
7  ADB. 2015. ADB Brief “Southeast Asia and the Economics of Global Climate Stabilization”. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
9  ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance for Southeast Asia Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development Facility. 
Manila.

4 
preparing  projects  for  ADB  financing. 10 This  will  include  due  diligence  assessments  for 
(i) technical suitability; (ii) economic and financial viability; (iii) governance; and (iv) poverty impact 
and  social  and  gender  development  (including  supporting  specific  assessments  on  gender 
mainstreaming). The project will also prepare (i) project specific gender action plan; (ii) social and 
environment safeguards; and (iii) detailed engineering designs.11 During the implementation, 
lessons learned from previous projects will be incorporated into the preparation of new projects. 
 
14.  Output 2: Project implementation support, capacity development, and policy advice 
provided. The TA facility will provide the DMCs with (i) project start-up and implementation 
support; (ii) capacity development in procurement, financial management, safeguards, gender 
and social development, and project-related technical aspects; and (iii) policy advisory, sector 
assessments, and business development.12 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $3,850,000, of which (i) $3,200,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($2,000,000 from TASF 6 and 
$1,200,000 from TASF-other sources); (ii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Australia to be administered by ADB; and (iii) $150,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Multi Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility to be 
administered by ADB.13 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. ADB will explore 
cofinancing opportunities with other trust funds such as the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility, the People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation  Fund,  Urban  Climate  Change  Resilience  Trust  Fund,  Project  Readiness 
Improvement Trust Fund, High-Level Technology Fund, and other funds from development 
partners after approval of the TA facility.  
 
16.  The  governments  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff  time,  office 
accommodation,  office  supplies,  communication  facilities  for  consultants,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. Activities in each participating DMC will start after obtaining no-objection from their 
government. The governments were informed that approval of the TA facility does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division 
of the Southeast Asia Department of ADB will be responsible for the day-to-day implementation. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1. Procurement of office equipment 
if any will be through the consultants’ contract.

18.  Consulting services. Following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time 
to time) and its associated staff instructions, ADB will use quality-cost based selection method 
(90:10) and consultants qualifications selection method to select firms. The eight prequalified 
consulting  firms  under  the  first  Southeast  Asia  Agriculture,  Natural  Resources  and  Rural 
Development Facility will be invited to submit a proposal to prepare a specific ensuing project. 
For special technical and administrative inputs, individual consultant selection method or other 
open-competitive bidding method will be explored in consultation with the Procurement, Portfolio 
and Financial Management Department.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  administering  a  portion  of  technical  assistance  (TA)  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of 
Australia; (ii) ADB administering a portion of TA not exceeding the equivalent of $150,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi Donor Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility; and (iii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,200,000 on a grant 
basis for the Southeast Asia Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural Development Facility – 
Phase II, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
                Masatsugu Asakawa 
29 April 2020              President

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ANR  –  agriculture, natural resources and rural development 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.
